description: From French fibre, from Old French fibre, from Latin fibra.

nouns.description: fiber (countable and uncountable, plural fibers) (American spelling)

entries.meaning: (countable) A single elongated piece of a given material, roughly round in cross-section, often twisted with other fibers to form thread.
examples: The microscope showed a single blue fiber stuck to the sole of the shoe.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) A material in the form of fibers.
examples: The cloth is made from strange, somewhat rough fiber.

entries.meaning: (textiles) A material whose length is at least 1000 times its width.
examples: Please use polyester fiber for this shirt.
Fresh vegetables are a good source of fiber.
The ordeal was a test of everyone's fiber.

entries.meaning: (mathematics) The preimage of a given point in the range of a map.
examples: Under this map, any two values in the fiber of a given point on the circle differ by 2Ï€.

entries.meaning: (category theory) The pullback of a morphism along a global element (called the fiber of the morphism over the global element).
(computing) A kind of lightweight thread of execution.
(cytology) A long tubular cell found in bodily tissue.
examples: Hyponyms: axon, myocyte, muscle fiber, nerve fiber
